content:
The unashamedly intellectual discussion series turns 20

LISTENERS to BBC Radio 4 on October 15th 1998 would have heard the Cumbrian-<span class="word-wrap-span">inflectspan>ed voice of Melvyn <span class="word-wrap-span">Braggspan> introduce a new programme without much <span class="word-wrap-span">fanfarespan>. He welcomed those tuned in to a series “in which I hope we’ll be looking at some of the ideas and events which have influenced the century”. 

In that first <span class="word-wrap-span">episodespan> of “In Our Time”, two academics <span class="word-wrap-span">soberlyspan> discussed the wars of the past 100 years. Since then, the show has explored more than 800 subjects, such as the 18th-century <span class="word-wrap-span">ginspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">crazespan>, <span class="word-wrap-span">Agrippinaspan> the Younger and the <span class="word-wrap-span">mathematicalspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">constantspan> e . “In Our Time” has the feel of a university <span class="word-wrap-span">seminarspan>, with some of <span class="word-wrap-span">academiaspan>’s brightest—Mary Beard and Marcus du Sautoy are regular contributors—taking 45 minutes each week to discuss a topic, live and unedited. The programme’s return this month continues its <span class="word-wrap-span">marathonspan> run into a 21st year. For the BBC, “In Our Time” is not just part of the <span class="word-wrap-span">furniturespan> but a load-bearing <span class="word-wrap-span">pillarspan>, propping up the <span class="word-wrap-span">corporationspan>’s <span class="word-wrap-span">occasionspan>ally wayward efforts to <span class="word-wrap-span">enlightenspan> the public. 

If the radio programme <span class="word-wrap-span">evokespan>s an academic <span class="word-wrap-span">enclavespan>, then Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Braggspan> is both the <span class="word-wrap-span">insufferablespan> swot and, on <span class="word-wrap-span">occasionspan>, the <span class="word-wrap-span">fresherspan> who forgot to complete the readings. He is far from a perfect <span class="word-wrap-span">moderatorspan>. He will frequently <span class="word-wrap-span"><span class="word-wrap-span">interrupspan>tspan> his guests mid-flow (listeners <span class="word-wrap-span">inevitablyspan> take to Twitter to lament the <span class="word-wrap-span"><span class="word-wrap-span">interrupspan>tspan>ion of a female contributor), often seems <span class="word-wrap-span">crotchetyspan> and <span class="word-wrap-span">occasionspan>ally ties himself in <span class="word-wrap-span">knotspan>s with his questions. Despite these idiosyncrasies, he succeeds in making often <span class="word-wrap-span">complexspan> and <span class="word-wrap-span">obscurespan> subjects <span class="word-wrap-span">approachablespan> and interesting. Will Self, an author, described him as “the dilletante’s dilletante”, and his <span class="word-wrap-span">eagerspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">curiosityspan> is <span class="word-wrap-span">contagiousspan>. Indeed, few broadcasters could sustain an audience of millions with a discussion of the sixth-century legal code of <span class="word-wrap-span">Justinianspan>. 

In its two decades the show has expanded its reach well beyond middle England. In 2005 producers asked listeners to suggest their favourite <span class="word-wrap-span">philosopherspan> to be featured in a future programme. They received 30,000 responses , with Karl Marx declared the <span class="word-wrap-span">eventualspan> winner. ( The Economist encouraged any readers hoping to <span class="word-wrap-span">fendspan> off a victory of the <span class="word-wrap-span">proletariatspan> to vote for David <span class="word-wrap-span">Humespan> instead.) Today, in addition to a weekly listenership of over 2m, each month the show is downloaded about 2.5m times as a <span class="word-wrap-span">podcastspan>. Over half of these listeners do so from outside Britain.

In many ways “In Our Time” makes for a better <span class="word-wrap-span">podcastspan> than broadcast show. History <span class="word-wrap-span">podcastspan>s rival true crime as the downloads du jour , thanks to shows such as the <span class="word-wrap-span">Watergatespan>-<span class="word-wrap-span">recountspan>ing “Slow Burn” and “<span class="word-wrap-span">Revisionistspan> History” from <span class="word-wrap-span">Malcolmspan> Gladwell, a journalist. The few minutes of bonus material on each download of “In Our Time” free it from the time <span class="word-wrap-span">constraintspan>s of live radio, and guests often spar over what was included in—or <span class="word-wrap-span">omittedspan> from—the broadcast. Taken together, the heaving online archive of “In Our Time” is a digital Library of <span class="word-wrap-span">Alexandriaspan>, a rich <span class="word-wrap-span">seamspan> of <span class="word-wrap-span">commutespan>-enhancing, dinner-party-reviving wisdom freely available to mine. 

Simon Tillotson, the show’s producer—and the voice calling time with the offer of a cup of tea at the end of each <span class="word-wrap-span">podcastspan>—<span class="word-wrap-span">attributespan>s its popularity to the guests’ generosity with their knowledge and the unrehearsed sparkiness of the discussion: “It’s a live exchange of ideas, which seems to be compelling.” The unabashed high-<span class="word-wrap-span">browspan> feel of “In Our Time” probably won’t help the BBC fight any <span class="word-wrap-span">accusationspan>s of <span class="word-wrap-span">elitismspan>, but the strength of its fan base might. The show’s <span class="word-wrap-span">catholicspan> range of subjects, respect for listeners’ intelligence and its quality of insight mean that “In Our Time” <span class="word-wrap-span">endurespan>s in a time when shrinking attention spans and an <span class="word-wrap-span">abundancespan> of poorly <span class="word-wrap-span">citespan>d information can make well-informed intellectual discussion tricky to find. Even as the number of <span class="word-wrap-span">installmentspan>s approaches four figures, there are plenty of stones left unturned.

ex: n. 修正主义者
adj. 修正主义的
持修正主义论的

wp.revisionist power: 修正主义国家;修正主义强国

ex: n. 水门，水闸；水门事件

wp.Watergate Case: 水门事件;水管门阀事件

eg2: Since , we have tried to make government as open as possible.
自从水门事件以来，我们试图让我们的政府尽可能地公开。
His involvement in the  evaporated any hope Nixon had for a political career.
尼克松同水门丑闻的牵连使他从政的希望化为乌有。
Particularly if you have got an incumbent president and we no longer stick to the public financing, which was a result of the Watergate scandal.
特别是如果你有一个现任总统，同时我们也不再坚持使用公共资金作为竞选经费，那样的话就会发生水门事件那样的丑闻。

wp.abundance standard: 丰度标准星;丰度尺度星
wp.abundance ratio: 丰度比;含量比例;存在比
wp.relative abundance: 相对丰度;元素丰度;相对多度;相对丰富度

ex: n. 充裕，丰富
eg2: They have an abundance mentality.
她们有丰富的心理世界。
There is an  of things to talk about regarding the holidays — so go for it.
关于假期有非常丰富的事情可以讲，所以要把它提出来大家一起讨论。
Welcome to the age of information .
欢迎来到这信息丰足的时代。

wp.The Academia: 新保学术苑;国家美术馆
wp.Academia Graz: 亚克德米亚格拉茨酒店

ex: n. 学术界；学术生涯
eg2: The newcomers will have some of the most enviable jobs in .
这些新头儿们将拥有学术界中最令人羡慕的工作。
These characteristics are not just important in our business, but in every business, as well as in government, philanthropy, and .
这 些特征不仅仅对我们的行业非常的重要，对任何行业都是如此，政府部门，慈善事业还有学术界。
I have yet to see serious discussion of it in either  or the real world.
而在学术界或真实世界中，却没有发现与之相关的严肃探讨。

ex: n. 控告，指控；谴责

wp.accusation evidence: 检举证据;指控证据;控告的证据

eg2: Lyndon was exonerated from the  of cheating.
林登被免受进行欺骗的指控。
He evidenced his  with some material evidence.
他以一些物证作为控告的证据。
Were they en route to a public , a mass trial or sentencing or even a mass execution?
他们是要去接受公众控告，群众审讯或者是判决抑或甚至是一场群众处决？

ex: adj. 亲切的；可接近的
eg2: So very analytical and very easy going in the sense that I am very .
所以我非常善于分析，非常容易相处，也就是说我很适合交谈。
While Western diplomats have welcomed Rice and her polite,  style, she has not impressed everyone.
虽然西方外交官欢迎赖斯和她礼貌亲切的作风，但是她并没有取悦所有人。
Designed to be more , NEUTRAL is a reassessment of the traditional power drill to make it easier for non-handy people like myself.
拥有更加亲切的设计，NEUTRAL为传统电钻做了一个新的诠释。 对于像笔者这样不熟练的人来说，电钻更加易于使用。

ex: n. 属性；特质
vt. 归属；把…归于

wp.Attribute data: 属性资料;		属性数据;计数值;计数数据通过计数得到的不能连续取值的离散型数据
wp.attribute list: 属性列表;		属性表;属性的列表输出;属性清单
wp.attribute definition: 属性定义;属性定义属性定义;属性界说
wp.prime attribute: 主属性;拄性;主要属性;翻译
wp.attribute testing: 质量分类试验;特性试验;属性检定
wp.Attribute Description: 属性描述;属性说明;特征描述;翻译
wp.required attribute: 必要的属性;必要属性;必填验证;必要项

eg2: Each level should have exactly one caption .
每个级别都应该有一个标题属性。
To accomplish this, you should begin by figuring out which element the attribute appears on.
要完成这项任务，应该首先确定这个属性出现在哪个元素上。
And from these, notice the name of the class and the name and type of each .
从这些标记中，我们可以看出类名和每个属性的名字与类型。

ex: n. 额头；山脊；坡顶
网络 眉毛；眉，眉毛；眼眉
eg2: The nurse mopped his fevered brow.
护士擦拭了他发烫的前额。
Her brow furrowed in concentration.
她眉头紧锁全神贯注。
The path disappeared over the brow of the hill.
小径过山顶后消失了。

ex: adj. 全体基督教徒的；基督教会的；包罗万象的；广泛的

eg2: to have catholic tastes(= to like many different things)
爱好广泛的

wp.quote cite: 引用前人事例或着作作为明证

ex: vt. 引用；传讯；想起；表彰
eg2: He continues to cite the article as evidence of his legitimacy.
他不断引用该文章作为自己研究合法性的证据。
This research tool will help you collect, organize and appropriately cite any sources you find over the Web.
这个研究工具会帮助你收集、组织并适当地引用你在网上发现的任何资源。
The next time you hear someone cite these percentages, listen with a careful ear, for faulty analyses abound.
下次在你听到有人引用这些比例的时候，如果你仔细听，一定能听到错误的分析。

eg2: complex machinery
结构复杂的机器

ex: adj. 不变的；恒定的；经常的
n. [数] 常数；恒量
n. (Constant)人名；(德)康斯坦特
eg2: indulgence in bad habits brought about his ruin.
经常沉溺于恶习导致了他的毁灭。
vigilance is necessary in order to avoid accidents.
为了避免意外事故， 必须经常保持警惕。
The pages of the dictionary had curled up from constant use.
字典的书页由于经常使用都卷起来了。

ex: n. 约束；限制；限定；严管
网络 约束条件；拘束；强迫
eg2: constraints of time/money/space
时间╱资金╱空间的限制
financial/economic/legal/political constraints
财政╱经济╱法律╱政治约束
This decision will impose serious constraints on all schools.
这项决定将使所有的学校受到各种严格的限制。
At last we could relax and talk without constraint.
我们终于可以放松下来，无拘无束地谈话了。

ex: adj. 感染性的；会蔓延的

wp.contagious diffusion: 传染扩散;接触扩散;蔓延式扩散;性扩散
wp.contagious agalactia: 传染性无乳症;接触传染性无乳症;和传染性无乳症
wp.contagious catarrh: 鸡传染性卡他;鸡流行性感冒
wp.contagious s: 接触传染性的;传染性的;传染的;感染性的

eg2: Love, happiness and tranquility are all .
爱、幸福与宁静都是有感染力的。
This is both  and deadly and must be avoided at all costs.
这会传染且是致命的，必须不惜一切代价加以避免。
Attitude is  and it will help to motivate you, and even those around you, to drive you towards your goal.
态度是具有感染性的，它可以使你获得动力，甚至可以感染你周围的人，推动你向目标努力。

ex: n. 公司；法人（团体）；社团；市政当局

wp.News Corporation: 新闻集团;新闻公司;消息团体;新闻团体
wp.Sharp Corporation: 夏普;夏普公司;夏普株式会社;夏宝股份有限公司

wp.multinational corporation: 跨国公司;跨国集团;		多国公司;多国企业

wp.Intel Corporation: 英特尔公司;英特尔;美国英特尔公司;英代尔公司
wp.Microsoft Corporation: 微软公司;公司名称;美国微软公司;发行者

eg2: The corporation divested itself of its subsidiaries.
该公司把它的所有子公司都卖掉了。
Their mission was to crack into the computer system of a major .
他们的任务是侵入一家大公司的计算机系统。
They have decided to liquidate the  by the end of the next month.
他们已经决定在下月底之前对公司进行清理。

ex: n. 狂热
vi. 发狂；产生纹裂
vt. 使发狂；使产生纹裂

wp.panda craze: 疯狂熊猫;疯狂熊猫黄金版;熊猫黄金版
wp.Coffee Craze: 疯狂咖啡店;疯狂咖啡馆;咖啡厅
wp.Craze Rush: 莉莎经营服饰店;丽莎经营时装店;丽莎经营服装店
wp.Blood Craze: 血之狂热;血之狂热被动

eg2: I thank living during love ,it brought me .
爱情之中我感谢生活,它给我狂热.
Clearly, we have a fashion craze on our hands, or, um, feet.
很明显，我们现在有着一种时尚狂热在手，或者说，嗯，在脚上。
We took our two daughters out of the public school system when they reached middle-school age, just as the standardized testing craze was taking hold, and put them in private schools.
我们将我们的两个女儿在她们上初中的年纪是带出了公共学校系统，正是因为标准化测试狂热根深蒂固，转而将她们送进了私立学校。

ex: adj. 有怪想的，想入非非的；反复无常的
eg2: A lot of older people are  because they've been complaining all their lives.
很多老年人脾气暴躁，因为他们一辈子都在怨天尤人。
A long,  letter, as we might say in Chile: gloomy and irritable.
正像我们可能在智利所说的一封长长的、脾气暴躁的书信：令人扫兴和易怒。
Though still, the letters on the page live and breathe as the writer does,  and shaky with old age, hectic with youth, comfortably embracing as a mother.
纸上的字母虽然平静地躺着，却像作者一样具有生命力，吐露着气息，他们反复无常，一会跟老人一起晃动着，一会又和年轻人一起兴奋着，一会又像母亲一样安乐地相拥在一起。

ex: n. 好奇心；求知欲；珍品；罕见而有趣之物
网络 好奇号；有好奇心；火星探测车好奇号
eg2: Children show curiosity about everything.
儿童对一切事物都显露出好奇心。
a certain curiosity to see what would happen next
有点想知道下一步会发生什么事的好奇心
The letter wasn't addressed to me but I opened it out of curiosity .
那封信不是写给我的，然而我却出于好奇把它拆开了。
His answer did not satisfy my curiosity at all.
他的答复丝毫没有满足我的好奇心。
Sophie's curiosity was aroused by the mysterious phone call.
那个神秘的电话引起了索菲的好奇心。
intellectual curiosity
求知欲
‘Why do you ask?’ ‘Oh, just idle curiosity ’(= no particular reason) .
“你为什么要问？”“哦，只是好奇而已。”
The museum is full of historical curiosities.
这座博物馆有许多珍奇历史文物。

wp.Eager for: 不甘寂寞;渴望;迫切要;渴求
wp.eager a: 热切的;渴望的;热切渴望的
wp.eager evaluation: 及早求值;热情计算;急切评估
wp.Eager Loading: 预先加载;贪婪加载;积极式载入

ex: adj. 渴望的；热切的；热心的
n. (Eager)人名；(英)伊格
eg2: The girl in the shop is always eager to please every customer.
这位女店员总是很热心地对待每一位顾客。
They are mirrors, reflecting how eager the youth are to succeed like their icons.
这些照片是镜子，反映了年轻人渴望成功，犹如他们的偶像。
Usually I turn down anyone who seems too , but his place was right there and I was in no mood to start cycling round looking for anywhere else.
通常我会拒绝看上去太过热心的人，但是他的旅馆就在旁边，我也没有心情再骑车去找别的地方，于是就住进了他的旅馆。

ex: n. 精英主义；杰出人物统治论
n. 飞地（指在本国境内的隶属另一国的一块领土）；被包围的领土；被包围物
eg2: An unapologetic Russian-speaking enclave in independent Ukraine, it is bound to draw you in with its own brand of humour, warm Mediterranean air and tragic, yet glorious history.
敖德萨，一块在独立的乌克兰无需辩解的说俄语的飞地，他必定会用自己幽默，温暖的地中海空气，悲壮却辉煌的历史来吸引你。
The Federation and the Klingons were now at peace, and the Enterprise resembled a spaceborne United Nations, a bustling enclave safe enough for the crew to bring children with them.
星际联邦和克林贡现在和解了，进取号成了一个宇宙飞船上的联合国，一块忙乱热闹的飞地，安全到船员可以带着孩子生活。

wp.unabashed action: 毫不掩饰的行动;不折不扣的行动;行动总动员

ex: adj. 不害羞的；不畏惧的；厚脸皮的
eg2: Palin has no national experience and less than two years experience as governor, but she is  about that.
佩林没有全国性的政治经验，作为州长也只有不到两年，但是她本人却处之泰然。
To stand unscreened yet , self-confessed before the world, --how could one withhold belief in the face of such supreme self-confidence?
不用遮掩，也不害臊，自认不讳地站在世界面前---对这种超强的自信，我们怎能不相信呢？
As Tiffany pointed out, the  feminism of lingerie is in for spring, and it serves as a lovely counterbalance to that “borrowed from the boys” look.
正如蒂凡尼指出，在春天，穿女性内衣是公然的权利，它充当了一个可爱的抗衡力：“从男孩那借来”的观念。

adj. 未刊行的；未编辑的；未经审查的
网络 未经预演的；亂与无预演性；灵感乍现

wp.Wayward Pines: 黑松林;黑松镇;即本剧剧名;黑松林第二季

ex: adj. 任性的；不规则的；刚愎的
eg2: And behind the veil of secrecy there appears to be more hustle to crack down on , smaller exporters.
而且在神秘面纱背后，似乎有更急速的活动打击任性的、规模较小的出口商。
While Paul is describing this behavior as the result of wayward passions, the chief sin is idolatry and separation from the one true God.
虽然保罗描述这种行为为任性激情的结果，主要的罪来自偶像崇拜，将一个人与独一的真神分开。
The “start of work means an end to freedom, but also to doubt, intensity and wayward desires...
工作的开始意味着自由的结束，也同时是疑惑、不安和任性的欲望的终结……
